raw_text:
Troubled Marsh under SEC scrutiny
 
 The US stock market regulator is investigating troubled insurance broker Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions, the firm has said.
 
 The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked for information about transactions involving holders of 5% or more of the firm's shares. Marsh has said it is co-operating fully with the SEC investigation. Marsh is also the focus of an inquiry the New York attorney-general into whether insurers rigged the market. Since that inquiry was launched in October, Marsh has replaced its chief executive and held a boardroom shake-out to meet criticism by lessening the number of company executives on the board. Prosecutors allege that Marsh - the world's biggest insurance broker - and other US insurance firms may have fixed bids for corporate cover. This is the issue at the heart of the inquiry by New York's top law officer, Eliot Spitzer, and a separate prosecution of five insurers by the State of California. The SEC's investigation into so-called related party transactions includes dealings in the Trident Funds, managed by MMC Capital, the company's private equity firm. Marsh's new chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, is trying to negotiate a settlement with Mr Spitzer. Mr Spitzer has built up a reputation as a fierce critic and campaigner against corporate America's misdeeds.
 
 The uncertainty unleashed by the scandal has prompted three credit rating agencies - Standard & Poor's, Moody's and Fitch - to downgrade Marsh in recent weeks. According to the Financial Times, insurance analysts are now questioning whether Marsh will be able to maintain its strong record of earning growth as they draw up forecasts for the first quarter of next year. Doubts also exist over how much the company may have to pay regulators and lawyers to put the scandal behind.
llama3.2:1b: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating troubled insurance broker Marsh & McLennan for its shareholder transactions, including dealings with 5% or more shareholders.
Marsh has cooperated fully with the SEC investigation but replaced its CEO and held a boardroom shake-out to address criticism.
The inquiry is also ongoing in New York, where attorney-general Eliot Spitzer is investigating whether insurance companies have rigged the market.
The SEC's investigation includes deals involving the Trident Funds managed by MMC Capital, which has recently hired new executives to deal with the scandal.
llama3.2:3b: The US Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating troubled insurance broker Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions, which involve holders of 5% or more shares.
The investigation includes dealings with a private equity firm, MMC Capital.
Meanwhile, New York Attorney-General Eliot Spitzer is probing whether insurers, including Marsh, rigged the market by fixing bids for corporate cover.
gemma2:2b: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions.
The SEC inquiry follows an investigation by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer alleging that Marsh along with other US insurance firms fixed bids for corporate cover.
This investigation has caused a downgrade of Marsh's credit rating, prompting questions about its ability to maintain earnings growth.

The SEC's investigation into related party transactions includes dealings in Trident Funds and managed by MMC Capital.
Insurance analysts are questioning whether Marsh will be able to maintain its strong record of earning growth and regulators and lawyers may have to pay extra for the scandal.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US stock market regulator investigating troubled Marsh & McLennan shareholder transactions; SEC request information on 5%+ shareholdings, co-operating with investigation; replaced CEO following New York attorney-general's inquiry into insurers' market rigging claims; facing potential SEC prosecution; uncertainty prompts credit rating agency downgrades and analyst questioning growth prospects and regulatory costs.
qwen2.5:3b: US stock market regulator SEC investigates troubled insurance broker Marsh & McLennan over shareholder transactions.
The firm is also under New York Attorney-General Eliot Spitzer's inquiry into potential market manipulation by insurers, including Marsh.
Since September, Marsh has replaced its CEO and reshuffled board members in response to criticism.

Three credit rating agencies have downgraded Marsh following the scandal, raising doubts about the company’s ability to maintain growth forecasts and potentially facing significant financial penalties.

Marsh also made mention of replacing its CEO and held an inquiry into various firms' business practices.

The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has asked for information about transactions involving holders of 5% or more of the firm's shares.
Marsh has said it is co-operating fully with the SEC investigation.
Marsh is also the focus of an inquiry by New York Attorney-General Eric Schneiderman into whether insurers rigged the market.
Since that inquiry was launched in October, Marsh has replaced its chief executive and held a boardroom shake-out to meet criticism by lessening the number of company executives on the board.
Prosecutors allege that Marsh - the world's biggest insurance broker - and other US insurance firms may have fixed bids for corporate cover.
This is the issue at the heart of the inquiry by New York's top law officer, Eliot Spitzer, and a separate prosecution of five insurers by the State of California.
The SEC's investigation into so-called related party transactions includes dealings in the Trident Funds, managed by MMC Capital, the company's private equity firm.
Marsh's new chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, is trying to negotiate a settlement with Mr Spitzer.
Mr Spitzer has built up a reputation as a fierce critic and campaigner against corporate America's misdeeds.
The uncertainty unleashed by the scandal has prompted three credit rating agencies - Standard & Poor's, Moody's and Fitch - to downgrade Marsh in recent weeks.

According to the Financial Times, insurance analysts are now questioning whether Marsh will be able to maintain its strong record of earning growth as they draw up forecasts for the first quarter of next year.
Doubts also exist over how much the company may have to pay regulators and lawyers to put the scandal behind.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Troublesome Marsh under SEC scrutiny  
The U.S. stock market regulator is investigating MMC's shareholder transactions and regulatory violations.
The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has asked for information on transactions involving 5% or more shares of MMC.
MMC has confirmed full cooperation with the SEC investigation.
MMC also faces an inquiry from New York attorney general regarding whether insurers rigged markets.
MMC, the world's largest insurance broker, is under scrutiny as it replaces CEO and meets criticism by reducing its executive board.
Pro Prosecutors allege that MMC and other US insurers may have fixed corporate cover bids.
The inquiry includes deals with MMC's private equity firm, Trident Funds, involving related parties.
The SEC's probe covers various transactions, including merger rumors and securities violations.
MMC is expected to face regulatory scrutiny, analyst doubts about its strong growth record, and issues over payments to regulators.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US stock market regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), has launched a probe into Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions after receiving information on their involvement in 5% or more of the firm's shares.
This investigation has focused on whether insurer firms rigged the market through bid fixing.
Prosecutors allege that Marsh, along with other US insurance companies, may have rigged the bids for corporate cover.
The SEC is investigating related party transactions and private equity deals managed by MM Capital, a subsidiary of Marsh.

The uncertainty surrounding the investigation has led three credit rating agencies to downgrade Marsh in recent weeks, with analysts questioning its ability to maintain growth as they draw up forecasts for the first quarter of next year.
The probe is reportedly casting doubts on whether Marsh will be able to pay regulators and lawyers to put it behind the scandal.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US stock market regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), is currently investigating troubled insurance broker Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions.
This follows a period of intense scrutiny by the New York attorney-general’s office into whether insurers rigged the market.
Marsh has cooperated fully with this investigation, and the firm has replaced its CEO and conducted a shakeout in board management as part of a broader restructuring process.
The inquiry was launched by New York attorney-general Eliot Spitzer in October and has focused on whether Marsh violated the securities laws.
Prosecutors allege that Marsh, the world's largest insurance broker, and other US insurers may have fixed bids for corporate cover.
This is the issue at the heart of the inquiry by New York’s top law officer, Eliot Spitzer, and a separate prosecution of five insurers by the State of California.
The SEC's investigation into related party transactions involves deals in the Trident Funds managed by MMC Capital, one of Marsh’s private equity investors.
The company's new CEO, Michael Cherkasky, is trying to negotiate a settlement with the SEC and has hired a lawyer to represent him.
The uncertainty created by the scandal has raised concerns about Marsh's ability to maintain its strong record of earnings growth.
Analysts are now questioning whether the company can recover from this setback and meet its forecasts for the first quarter of next year.
Marsh's credit rating is under pressure, with Standard & Poor’s, Moody’s, and Fitch all downgrading their outlook in recent weeks.
This suggests that investors may be questioning whether Marsh can weather the storm caused by the scandal.

This follows an inquiry by New York's attorney-general into whether insurers may have rigged bids for corporate cover.
Credit rating agencies have downgraded Marsh following the scandal, raising concerns about the company's future growth and potential financial liabilities.

The company has been under scrutiny since October due to allegations of related-party transactions involving the Trident Funds managed by MMC Capital.
Three credit rating agencies downgraded Marsh in recent weeks following the inquiry launched by New York's top law officer, Eliot Spitzer.
The uncertainty unleashed by the scandal has prompted three credit rating agencies to downgrade Marsh in recent weeks.
Insurance analysts are now questioning whether Marsh will be able to maintain its strong record of earning growth as they draw up forecasts for the first quarter of next year.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions, focusing on those involving significant shareholders.

This investigation follows a broader inquiry by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleging that major US insurance firms, including Marsh, may have colluded to fix corporate insurance bid prices.
Marsh has replaced its CEO and reduced board membership in response to these concerns.
The SEC's related party transaction inquiry includes dealings in the Trident Funds managed by MMC Capital, a private equity firm under Marsh.
Marsh's new CEO, Michael Cherkasky, is attempting to negotiate a settlement with Spitzer.
Credit rating agencies have downgraded Marsh due to the scandal, and insurance analysts question whether the company can sustain its earning growth forecasts for the first quarter of next year.
The financial impact of the scandal also remains uncertain.
